intro: Lippia sellowii, commonly known as Brazilian pepper or wild thyme, is a flowering plant native to South America. It is a member of the Verbenaceae family and is characterized by its aromatic, fragrant leaves. The plant typically grows as a shrub, reaching heights of up to 1 meter, with opposite, ovate leaves that are often covered in fine hairs. Its small, tubular flowers are usually pink or purple and are arranged in clusters at the ends of the branches. Lippia sellowii is valued for its medicinal properties and is used in traditional medicine for its antiseptic and anti-inflammatory effects.
